Corporate Participants

* Sean E. Reilly

Lamar Advertising Company (REIT) - CEO

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: All right. Why don't we get started with our next session. I'm pleased to welcome to the stage Sean Reilly, the CEO of Lamar, a position he has held since 2011. Prior to that, he held a variety of leadership roles at Lamar, including COO and President of Outdoor since 2001. Great. Thanks for being here.

SEAN E. REILLY, CEO, LAMAR ADVERTISING COMPANY (REIT): Appreciate having me. Thanks.

Questions and Answers

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Let's start out and talk a little bit about the broader U.S. outdoor industry. The growth this year has been incredibly strong, up 7% overall. Growth is clearly coming from the larger markets. Can you talk about your view on sort of the sector growth and the factors that are driving this?

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. Great question. First of all, you've got an industry that's in the best place I've seen it, and I've been doing this a long time. The other 2 big companies in the industry are hitting their stride. You've got Clear Channel that is now independent, on their own, able to reinvest in the industry in a way that was difficult for them when they were a part of iHeart and going through bankruptcy, so that's a good thing. Jeremy at Outfront, they're executing extremely well, and in particular executing on converting large market transit from analog to digital. That's fueling growth and advertiser interest in our medium. It is true that larger markets are doing better than the smaller markets and medium-sized markets as we speak. But I've been doing this a long time, that ebbs and flows. But the 7% traditional medium has been around for 100-some-odd years, that's a good place to be. And finally, I would add that increasingly, our customers are using what I will call our big digital screen to augment what they're doing on the little screen. And there's many ways they can do it. They can use geo-fencing to have what shows up on the big screen show up on an app on the little screen. They can use what's trending on their Facebook, Twitter or webpage app to inform what goes on the big screen, right? So that copy is always relevant and changing in a timely fashion for what's happening here. So that, I think, is what's going on. And I think ultimately what they're finding, our customers, is that out-of-home is just a great complement for them.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: That's an interesting point because I mean is that sort of your assessment of sort of the variance, the dispersion of growth? We're seeing large versus small market? Because we all know that large markets tend to have heavier national advertising, where you might have a little bit more sophistication, if I could use that word, maybe tapping into some of the mobile and digital aspects, where...

SEAN E. REILLY: We have very sophisticated local advertisers in places like Oklahoma City and Baton Rouge and Tallahassee and Little Rock and sort of middle-market USA that are very sophisticated with this and are very up to speed on how they can use out-of-home in conjunction with this. The larger market phenomenon is largely entertainment and big tech, wildly enthusiastic about high-spot, large-format out-of-home in places like L.A., San Fran and New York. But again, that bodes well for the industry and it will trickle down to Baton Rouge.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Are there things that you could do or trying to do to try to attract some of those dollars, those entertainment companies, big tech -- and it doesn't have to be big tech, because as Jeremy has mentioned, it's also some of these start-up companies. Well, I guess some of the start-ups are too big. But at any rate, is that something you're focused on trying to lure those dollars to some of those mid-markets?

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. I actually think the most fertile ground is going to be the streaming work that are going to be upon us shortly. Because the nature of their original content is slicing and dicing demographics a little more thinly than blockbuster movies. Historically, the big blockbuster productions limited their out-of-home spend to outside DMA. But as you slice the demographic more narrowly, I mean, let's say it's a Netflix coming out with a documentary about veterans, and they want to be having out-of-home presence near every army base in the country. Well that's a different buy, and that makes sense for them. That actually happens to be a true story. So I think that's going to be our big opportunity.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And what role do you think the strength of the U.S. macroeconomy is playing on this growth? Because I was looking at this in preparation for these questions, and this 7% growth, the last time in the industry is at this level was right before the '08, '09, I mean, is it...

SEAN E. REILLY: You had to go there, didn't you?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I got to (inaudible) on the -- I don't know, it's a tough question, but I'd love to hear your...

SEAN E. REILLY: Well, to a certain degree, we're tethered to GDP, we're tethered to the U.S. domestic ad spend. We can't stray too far away from that. But I believe that there are some secular tailwinds that are helping us grow slightly faster than GDP. There's share shift going on at the local level. Other traditional media are struggling with their audience. Our audience is growing. You guys are spending more time in your community than ever before. That's a good thing. So yes, I think to a certain extent, it's -- we are enjoying pretty decent economy. To a certain extent, we've got some secular tailwinds helping us.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can you talk a little bit about the local national split of your business? Your overwhelmingly (inaudible) orders of 80% locally driven. Your national growth has -- this year has been a little bit slower. Can you talk about sort of what's going on there and currently (inaudible).

SEAN E. REILLY: Sure. In general, across both local and national, the back half is a little stronger than the first. As I mentioned, I've been doing this a long time. Local tends to, over time, grow like this, a little more steady. National tends to have a higher beta. When you smooth it out over time, they tend to grow at the (inaudible). We are going through a spurt here where national is a little stronger. Our Q3 national looks like it's going to be sort of plus or minus up 7% so we are enjoying a little national spurt. So that's a good thing. But you know when you look at Clear and Upfront, their mix is more sort of 55-45, and we're 23% national, 77% local.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. So I guess that national perking up to 7% or so. On some of the past calls you've mentioned there is some issues with I think one of your restaurant clients and you're -- they were shifting their budget around, and so it looks like that that's kind of playing out as expected?

SEAN E. REILLY: That's helping. Yes. That is helping.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: They depressed in the first half and they pushed it in the back half and so, that's great.

SEAN E. REILLY: Correct. Aggregate dollars are the same, just cadence of the buy was a little bit different.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And then on the local side, you're obviously lapping political pipes mostly in 4Q, maybe a little bit than 3Q. Your guidance sort of calls for an acceleration, it seems, on -- even on that local level. I think some investors have wondered, can you really pick up the growth even though you're facing -- you don't political this year in light of that.

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. So yes, that's a little bit of a headwind. But fortunately this year, we made the leap into programmatic and to kind of put a finer point on that, our traditional channels are tapping into traditional ad budget, be they national, be they local, be they agencies or be they touched by our 1,000 account executives around the country. The digital pie has traditionally never even looked data because we don't speak their language and that's the language of programmatic (inaudible). This year, we -- well, we spent last year pulling together our pipes so that we could execute. And we established relationships with SSPs and quasi-DSPs to help us connect to the customers' programmatic platform. It was a science project last year, it's a real business this year. And the way it works is we actually pay a call on the digital buying shop with end customer, let's call it (inaudible) their digital operation. And we go with the DSP/SSP that we're working with. In this case, with 4 that was Vistar. Ian Dallimore is our Head of Digital growth. Ian will be there. And we convinced them to take some portion of a buy that's destined to go here and allocate it to digital out-of-home. So there is a human making a decision that I want to be there. Doesn't guarantee us the buy because we then load our CPM, the demographic that our units are going to hit in the markets they desire, and then they drop it in the algorithm. And if it hits, we get the buy, if it doesn't hit, we don't get the buy. There is a little bit of preprogramming in there that we know where we need to put the CPM to make sure we're hitting that part of it. And it's been a real fruitful exercise this year. I think we'll end up doing about $12 million in billings and it's growing every month, and it is replacing the political ad in the back half last (inaudible).

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: (inaudible) client-by-client?

SEAN E. REILLY: On a client-by-client -- we put -- I put in 2 business rules when my team said that they wanted to do this. Number one, don't put our inventory in an auction environment. That's what happened to the digital publishers 4, 5 years ago. They lost control of their pricing. So let's make sure that doesn't happen. And number two, let's make sure it's net new customers. And I can say with a great deal of confidence that these beginning stages of the game, it's net new dollars because these are digital buying shops that had no way of accessing our inventory, no -- really even new that's (inaudible) fewer available to them.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And this is predominantly local or national customers?

SEAN E. REILLY: Right now, it's predominantly national.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And each outdoor company at some level of deploying the type of technology, it's kind of interesting because a lot of advertising historically has sort of been uniform measurements and comparability. In this environment, everybody's got something slightly differently, so it makes it hard for advertisers maybe to (inaudible) Outfront or (inaudible). Do you view that as an impediment to billing? How important is this (inaudible) clients making a decision? How important is the (inaudible) ad tech?

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. I think we're gravitating slowly in the same direction on the way we deploy ad tech. We're not there now. Outfront has a proprietary black box that they've built that has their data sets and their attribution and their programmatic approach. I think that's a battled approach. Clear Channel has a model that's a little more open. They've developed and branded RADAR. Our approach has been to use third-party data providers, develop our own attribution tools that's not all that difficult, make sure that our programmatic platform and pipes are completely open architecture. So our API is open to whomever can help us. Right now, we work with 4 different, in addition to Vistar, 3 other DSP/SSP. So our approach has been open architecture, we use third-party data, pay for it on a campaign-by-campaign basis. So if we have a customer that comes in and says, "Look, I think this is the best data set to prove out our goals, and this is the best attribution approach for you to demonstrate efficacy, I'll pay for it, and let's go." And then another client may say, "Well, I have a different data set and I don't care about attribution or whatever," right? So we're trying to do it, again, third-party, open architecture, campaign by campaign.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Does that cost ever fall to you? Like it's -- do they require -- like sort of, it's obviously a decision you could make like with this data set, you should be paying for it and licensing it?

SEAN E. REILLY: It's a negotiation. Our intent is to sell our space for the best rate we can. In the instance of geo-fencing, we typically mark that up and take 50% of the profit and the other 50% goes to our geo-fencing partner. In most cases it's Blue Bite, right? And we are wrapping Blue Bite, that's why we take a commission on it, right? We are the one pitching the client that this geo-fencing in conjunction with out-of-home space is going to be a good return for you. In the case of data set and attributions, sometimes they'll pay for the data set and we'll pay for the attribution study or vice versa. But again, our goal is to sell space.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. Do you have a target in mind like how big could this sales channel be in a couple of years' time? How -- it's scaling rather quickly right now and it seems like you're just scratching the surface, but I don't know if you have sort of targets of where it could be?

SEAN E. REILLY: So right now, we've walled off our other traditional channels. So we don't allow local customers that our account executives talk to, to use it even though some would be sophisticated enough to do it. And we don't let traditional agencies use it or traditional buying services use it. So we've walled them off. To really scale it, we're probably going to have to open it up. And you know, the pitfall there is I can't guarantee if it's going to be net dollars if I do that, right? So we're going to be careful. I can see it being the predominant channel, right? But to get there, we would have to open it up to our other customer base, and then it's -- I couldn't sit here and tell you it's all incremental net new dollars.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: But that's not necessarily a bad thing because what's the -- you guys are controlling the pricing, right? So you are clear about that, which makes complete sense. I'm trying to think what's the downside of just making it more -- not -- breaking down that wall?

SEAN E. REILLY: So the downside is, right now, my cost of sale, the sales commission I pay to third-party vendors like Vistar that are -- have access to our inventory, we're using their pipes and they're pitching us. It costs me 10%. My otherwise all-in cost of sales runs about 7%, right? So if I make this the predominant pipe and I don't figure out the difference between these 2 -- how to get it down to 7%, I'm going to lose 3 points of margin. So right now, that's where we are, but we'll figure that out. We will figure that out.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Interesting. I mean, yes, I guess, as it scales, there might be other efficiencies that you find, I guess is probably your thoughts of don't rush it yet. Interesting. Okay. Taking on sort of the theme of technology. Let's talk a little bit about digital boards. You're on track to add over 200 this year, a little bit slower, I think, than what you did. 250 is what you expected to do at the beginning of the year, but in the ballpark. Can you just give us a sort of broad update on how this year is tracking and your outlook for digital conversions over the next couple of years?

SEAN E. REILLY: We're going to go as fast as we can. I mean you've been following us a long time in the early days of this. There were periods where we got out a little in front of demand, primarily because our client base hadn't really fully embraced it, didn't really know how to use it, didn't know how to complement this with the big screen. But now, it seems to me there's a very large appetite out there, where our same board growth is strong and we track that and tell you guys how we're doing with that every quarter. As long as that's flashing green, we're going to build as many as we can. This year was a tad slower than we thought, I think primarily because we did the big Fairway acquisition. We inherited 100 or so digitals from them and we had to integrate them into our NOC and do some other things. So hopefully, we can get back up to that 250 pace.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And maybe just remind us of some of the gating factors. And you said that you're trying to be moving as fast as you can. What are the impediments to moving faster, notwithstanding Fairway, that's kind of unique situation but sort of normal course, what are the things that are slowing you down?

SEAN E. REILLY: Well, the regulatory environment has to be navigated. It's not necessarily unfriendly, but it takes time, you got permits, you got different regulations, you got a -- sometimes you have to do a little horsetrading with the municipality. These are little construction projects, right? You got to have trucks and crews. And you got to have equipment show up. And there's -- so there's some logistics that also are just part of the game. If I could snap my fingers, it would go a lot faster. But unfortunately, we just have to navigate that.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. And -- yes, this has been going on for more than a decade now. Can you talk about sort of how the ROIs have evolved over time as you've gotten sort of deeper into this conversion process?

SEAN E. REILLY: The ROIs have gotten better because the cost of the technology is going down, basically. I think we've wrung most of that out. When we started doing this, a 14 x 48 digital unit that lasted 7 years and didn't have quite the same resolution and weighed a lot more and used a lot more energy cost $500,000, right? That was what we were doing a decade ago. And today, on a 14 x 48, let's say $160,000 to $170,000, weighs a lot less, lasts a lot longer, uses a lot of less electricity, has a crisper picture as the resolution is better. So it's just all better, as we -- but I do think we've wrung the cost that's about down about it best we can.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. And what sort of the useful life that you're seeing now? It used to be 7, and is it...

SEAN E. REILLY: It used to be 7. Now we're getting warranties from the manufacturer that are 11, 12.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Wow. Yes. And when you guys think of -- it must be in your maintenance CapEx or I don't know if you put it in maintenance or how you treat it when you report it, but you're obviously going through some replacements.

SEAN E. REILLY: Replacements.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Is that in -- that's in maintenance?

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. So if we are replacing one that was a previous generation that's maintenance CapEx, I'm going to guess this year might be off about a little bit. But something in the neighborhood of $16 million, $17 million of our maintenance CapEx is replacing old digital. We'll spend more than that on the new one, something in the neighborhood of $20-some million. But when we add up that bucket plus the rest of our maintenance CapEx, it's -- we think it's going to come in between $48 million, $50 million this year, and our total CapEx is going to come in around $120 million.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. I remember when -- back in the early days when this conversion started, the industry, yourself included, you were moving pretty fast and getting out there, and at some point you kind of realized, when you do these conversions, you're adding a lot of supply to the -- to an individual market and there may not be sufficient demand and you may have -- they may steal from your own static boards and then when you look at the whole picture, you're like, I don't know. Is that -- are you -- are we sort of well past that sort of phenomenon? You're obviously aware of the issue now and maybe adjust accordingly. But is that still a big consideration when you're looking at conversion potential?

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. We're just smarter now. We know what data points to look at, we know -- in most of Lamar land, we're the only digital provider, right? So if we do get a little out of our ski, a little ahead of ourself, we can kind of throttle back and modulate supply to meet demand. And we probably have some markets where we're perfectly happy where we are. We have some markets where 40% of the revenues are digital. And our local general manager says, look, my distribution is good, my customers are happy, I really don't need anymore right now. And then we have other markets where their penetration is at sort of 10% or 15% and they're saying, "I need more," right? So Lamar is a little bit different from our competitors in that yield management is 100% locally determined. Our local general managers have complete control of their P&L, top to bottom, they turn on the lights, turn off the lights, hire, fire. They scout out and request digital conversion. They do a pro forma on them. At corporate, we run it through ROI filter. We check their performance on digitals they have, and then if it fits all that criteria, we green light it. And then we build it into their budgets and hold them accountable for their capital deployed. So it's a bottom-up, local yield management exercise not dictated from Baton Rouge.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. Do you think they -- one of the benefits of digital, it seem to me, was that you could do things like dayparting and change the copy like during the day for, say, a restaurant, fast food or what have you. I mean do you feel like the advertisers are fully taking advantage of that? Or are they just -- yes. Okay.

SEAN E. REILLY: Absolutely. Yes. And that -- and again, that's why early on that we may have stepped back a little bit. But our advertisers are very sophisticated, they change their copy frequently, and a copy change is frictionless and costless for them as opposed to static. And so all those benefits are now sort of dawning on them and they're ready to go.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. What do you -- with the rest of your inventory, the static billboard inventory, which is still the bulk of your units, what are you seeing in terms of pricing and demand there? Because the digital -- yes, it's obvious like that should be strong or slight opportunity for growth, but is that starting to depress the static growth?

SEAN E. REILLY: It's, I think, had a little teeny effect on it. But we have customers that buy across both platforms and execute campaigns both in a static environment and a dynamic digital environment. Our static inventory, I would categorize it as occupancy is normalized and we're getting a little bit of bump in rate, particularly in bulletins because they're sold individually by location as opposed to posters that are sold in grouping. Just put a little finer point and how much is which. This year, we'll do about $400 million in digital revenues and that's growing high single-digit rates. That's on a base of $1.75 billion in revenues, give or take, this year. So give or take 23% and growing. The...

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And that's how single is...

SEAN E. REILLY: That includes additional.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. It's not same board.

SEAN E. REILLY: That's not same board, that's additional inventory as well. But you -- I mean you can see that it's -- where it's headed. There are places where -- like the U.K. where 60% of the revenues are digital. Now that's a little -- that's in the transit setting. So that's a little bit different than traditional conversions, but it suggests to me that there's a lot of running room.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Okay. Let's talk about transit a bit, which is actually not that big of a business for you guys. I think maybe 5% of your revenue thereabout. Your peers are heavily into it. Outfront scooped up some contracts, particularly here in New York and had some -- having some good early success with growth, top line growth on that. So you can talk about how you think about transit? Is that an area that you would consider getting larger in? Are you kind of happy with the mix of business you have now?

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. So we're middle-market, small-market transit. We feel about $90 million in revenues, maybe a little more, across 60 to 70 contracts. So lots of middle-market contracts. The -- it's a portfolio approach we take. We stay out of the top 20 DMAs, life is pretty fierce there. Life is a little more mellow in places like Albuquerque. And so we just manage that portfolio and when a middle-market opportunity comes up, we go for it. We typically find that there's not a lot of competition for those. And we're, by far, the biggest player in that patch. We virtually never run into Outfront in a transit setting in a bid. We're in the airport business as well. We have about 25 contracts, that business does about $40 million. Same philosophy, let's stay sort of middle-market, stay away from the JCDecaux and Clear Channel. When they battle over the Atlanta airport, we just kind of avoid that. And that business is a good little business. When you put them together, it's $130 million in revenues. Our operating margin on that is going to be about 15%, give or take. So it's slow margin business. But it's a fun business, I got to tell you. Airports in particular, a lot of great technologies you can deploy. We just redid the baggage claim in Vegas, so next time you're in Vegas in the baggage claim, you're going to see a bunch of digitals and we just did that. Enjoyed a nice lift when we did that. So yes, we're in the business. But it's not a large part of what we do.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And how important -- when you're looking at these contracts when they come up, how important is it that you have a billboard presence already. I mean is that a big opportunity?

SEAN E. REILLY: Doesn't matter. No. Doesn't matter.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Not a lot of cross-selling that goes on, I guess?

SEAN E. REILLY: It happens in some places. So we have the trains and the buses in Denver. And we have the #2 bulletin plant in Denver. And that has been a synergy that's worked well. But then on the other hand, if you've got the -- all of the billboards in Little Rock, and you're also doing the Little Rock airport, there's not a lot of synergies there. And so that -- it really just depends. I was listening to Jeremy talk about some of the synergies he enjoys in larger markets, and I think they're there because of scale of the businesses that can be bigger.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I guess you're just finding those smaller markets, a client really prefers one or the other for maybe...

SEAN E. REILLY: They don't buy across both, but we actually have separate sales forces. We have dedicated sales forces. So that one product doesn't become sort of the stepchild or the loss leader, which can happen if you have a single AE trying to sell both products. That really depends on the size of the market and how big each one of those enterprises is.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Do you find it's more national on some of those airport and transit or is it a mix?

SEAN E. REILLY: Airports can be a one-stop shop for national. They're trying to talk to a really tight demographic, traveling demographic.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Okay. You mentioned earlier that you did acquire Fairway Outdoor, which is one of the larger independents. You bought them at the end of last year, 8,500 boards, expanded your presence in DMAs outside the top 25. Can you talk about how that integration has gone and have the synergies come in as you expected?

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. That was a pretty predictable exercise on synergy side, predominantly cost, that happens really fast. We can take the expense base. I think the number was $4 million, give or take, on the savings there. And the synergies that we represented back in December when we announced the deal were virtually all on the expense side. We'll get some lift on the top line. That takes a little bit longer, but the integration on the expense side is virtually done. Happens pretty quick. And then on the revenue side, it's just slightly different approach to commissioning local salespeople, slightly different approach to how our general managers are compensated for performance against expectation in the P&L, and we find that our formula works pretty well when we step in and take over.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: In the cost synergies, is it mostly because on sales personnel, because you already have people in that market, is that...

SEAN E. REILLY: It's -- some of it is overlap inventory and people. The -- somewhat on the sales side, somewhat on the ops side, fewer trucks because we have overlap in fewer truck rolls, fewer trucks, fewer guys in trucks. In some cases, office buildings. We can consolidate into a nearby office building and get rid of the other one. So it's just kind of the typical synergy stuff that you would run into.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. Maybe -- I don't know, maybe on the static -- on the vinyl, I don't know if there's any operating cost taken out just on the static.

SEAN E. REILLY: We have a little bit of a buying advantage because we buy so much vinyl. We have a square footage reduction typically when we go in that an independent doesn't enjoy. So we have a little bit of that.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. And then on the same topic of just M&A but maybe speaking more broadly about the structure of the industry, there's obviously 3 big players. But there's still about maybe 1/3, 35% of market that's pretty highly fragmented.

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can you talk about the pipeline of M&A opportunities of sort of buying in more (inaudible)

SEAN E. REILLY: Sure. So traditionally, as you know, we've done kind of -- there's 3 types of M&A. We have sort of cookie-cutter fill-in M&A that just happened because of our footprint. If you go online and look at Lamar website, go to our Browse Inventory section in the map, the U.S. will come up and you'll see all our offices. And if you drill down, you'll see where all our inventory is by type. And the first thing you'll notice is that we're virtually everywhere. So most inventory that we purchased is going to be fill-in, which means we don't have to have people, we don't have to have trucks, we don't have to have offices, we're just buying structures, permits, ground leases and advertising contracts. Very predictable exercise. Year in and year out, we'll do $100 million to $150 million worth of that. And these are smaller transactions. $5 million, $10 million, $25 million. We don't even announce them. We just kind of tell you guys how much we've done every quarter because in and of themselves, they're not that significant, but when you add them all up, they're nicely accretive. We typically bring those in at about $10 million to $10.5 million our forward EBITDA contribution. From the seller's trailing point of view, it's a little richer than that. But again, we've got -- we don't have to have their people. There's a long tail of that. I mean there's a decade worth of that stuff.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: That's interesting, because I'm surprised it doesn't move faster especially as like maybe the need to convert to digital comes into play and that can be a bigger CapEx?

SEAN E. REILLY: There are actually some independents that have decided to sell because of that. They just don't -- they're a little intimidated by the whole digital conversion. But really, it's -- look, it's really a function of the fact that if you're an independent billboard operator, you're enjoying a good life. I mean it's a good kind of business. So -- and they don't have to sell. I mean we almost never have the opportunity to buy distressed properties. The billboard business is so strong. The second type of acquisition is sort of the DMAs where we're not -- there aren't very many of those left. Asset value, $250 million to $500-ish million, so larger independent. You can count on one hand the number of those that are still left out there. And then, of course, there's the speculation around some transformative thing with the big 3. You know, hey.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: It's been going on. It's going on for a recent decade. That was sort of comments. Do you have sort of -- I mean do you think that changes? I mean is there some sort of catalyst? I mean, obviously, Clear Channel came through that bankruptcy process, kind of got spun off from iHeart. You guys have been sort of steady as she goes. Outfront has been -- it's 5 years now since they spun off CBS and so some of the tax restrictions, once they pass that 5-year anniversary, maybe potentially put in play. Do you think something actually happens here in the next couple of years?

SEAN E. REILLY: You know me, I don't tend to speculate much about this stuff. But like I said at the outset, the industry is in a great place. Clear Channel, in particular, are doing all the things that you would expect a good company to do that's in it for the long pull, right? They've put together a world-class Board, they've got great management, they've taken their capital structure and taken it long. They are reinvesting in the business that, to me, looks like they're doing it for the long pull. So that one, I think it's incredibly good for the industry and reflects well on us when they're able to reinvest in their inventory and make our customers look good, right? And they're doing that, so that's a good thing. And Outfront is hitting their stride. I mean they have, since the last few years, making some -- I think some good investments in their inventory. It looks good. They've made some good investments in their technological platform. They've revamped the way they do local sales and I think that's paying off for them. So hey, I'm a cheerleader because, at the end of the day, there's not a lot of competitive friction between Lamar and the other 2. We only overlap in about 20% of our market. So I think that their success, number one, adheres to our benefit; and number two, the industry is ascendant and that's a good thing.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. So 20% overall. That's kind of one of the questions I wanted to ask is just whether the Department of Justice would allow any type of merger between the big 3. If it involves you guys, it sounds like that might be a little bit easier, but if it involves Outfront and Clear Channel, it could be a little bit harder.

SEAN E. REILLY: The one thing I can say is the antitrust landscape in the out-of-home world is very tricky. We haven't been through in a while, but it was a friendlier environment, I can tell you, in the late '90s, early 2000s than it is today. Some other companies have had to go through, and it was a pretty difficult exercise. So I wouldn't underestimate how tricky that environment is.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Do you think -- what's the definition of market when the DOJ looks at it? Are they just -- is it just outdoor advertising and -- or is it...

SEAN E. REILLY: Well, here is the frustrating part. We don't know. They're not consistent. There was one transaction, really small transaction, should have been green lighted from the get-go. And for whatever reason, they decided to define the relevant market as a radius around an individual billboard. Well, ouch. That was fairly pronounced. Typically what they have done in my experience is the relevant market is the entire DMA, and the relevant product is large format or small format. Now if they take that approach, you can solve issues with divestitures, right? You can, "Okay, I got this," right? But again, we don't know what approach they're going to take. Defining the market as all advertising and defining the DMA as the whole country, I don't see that happening.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. I get the DMA argument to some extent. I don't know that I get this billboard advertising versus all advertising. But they've been pretty consistently defining kind of -- like a couple of years ago, there was cinema advertising. There's only 2 players and they tried to -- that was a little bit tough because that would have been a monopoly, but they went narrow on that definition, just cinema advertising. It can be a monopoly, so they blocked it.

Maybe I'll see if there's any questions from the audience. Just raise your hand, we can get you a mic. Let me ask one about the AFFO. In the second quarter, you reiterated that you expect to be at the high end of your range, which is $567 million to $583 million. Can you give us an update, are you still comfortable with that? How are your cost and CapEx trending in the back half?

SEAN E. REILLY: We're going to get a little break on the interest that's helpful, right, given where rates are as opposed to where we thought they were going to be. CapEx should be right where it's supposed to be. Assuming that programmatic does what it's supposed to do, we should be bumping up against that -- the top end of that range. I'm glad you reminded everybody we're a REIT. Hey, everybody, we're a REIT. And we've got a great yield and -- yes.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. It's interesting. You do kind of forget it. I used to ask this question every year about like your shareholder base and sort of where you're seeing interest for investors because the REIT community was maybe a little skeptical or cautious when the billboards first converted. Do you feel like we're sort of past that?

SEAN E. REILLY: We still get a little bit of pushback. Some of the pushback we get is, we are perceived to be more cyclical than other real estate asset classes. I'm not quite convinced that's the case having done this for a long time and knowing a lot about real estate, but that's the perception. Because we don't own the ground under our structures, some REIT investors have a hard time doing NAV calc on us, and that can be an issue. I just hired a new CFO, Jay Johnson. He's a great guy, comes out of the REIT world. He was the CFO for DiamondRock Hospitality, a publicly traded REIT. He's really excited about getting in front of REIT investors and helping them understand the real estate attributes that are fundamental to our business model. So I think we're going to do better there, I really do. We're -- I hate to say it this way, because within the REIT world, we're cheap. On an AFFO multiple basis. So REIT investors are beginning to look at that and say, "You know, I think I can dip my toe in the water," and they are, so some of them are.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Okay. Well, Sean, we're out of time. Thank you very much for joining us.

SEAN E. REILLY: Great. I appreciate you having me. Thank you all.

urn:contentItem:60W4-7KX1-DXH2-649C-00000-00Lamar Advertising Co at Goldman Sachs Communacopia Conference (Virtual) - Final2020-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:37ZLexisNexis091620a13392893.793Lamar Advertising Co at Goldman Sachs Communacopia Conference (Virtual) - Final

Corporate Participants

* Sean E. Reilly

Lamar Advertising Company (REIT) - CEO & President

Conference Call Participants

* Daniel B. Powell

Goldman Sachs Group, Inc., Research Division - Associate

Presentation

DANIEL B. POWELL, ASSOCIATE, GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: Hi, my name is Daniel Powell, and I work in equity research at Goldman Sachs. Really appreciate everyone being here for the session with Lamar today. Especially want to say thank you to Sean Reilly, President and CEO of Lamar Advertising, for being with us here today during such a busy time. Thanks so much, Sean.

SEAN E. REILLY, CEO & PRESIDENT, LAMAR ADVERTISING COMPANY (REIT): Oh, Daniel, thanks for having me, and happy to be here.

Questions and Answers

DANIEL B. POWELL: So maybe a good place to kick things off and get started. 2020 has been quite the year, as you and I were talking about a little bit before the session. A lot has changed in a very short period of time. So maybe just a good place to start, particularly for investors who might be new to Lamar, is maybe describe to us what do we see at Lamar today, what is it that you and the leadership team built that we see at Lamar.

SEAN E. REILLY: Great, and good question to start with. We certainly have had some turnover in our shareholder base, so I'm happy to start with sort of what makes Lamar unique, and so what I'll start with is our footprint. We just absolutely dominate in middle-market USA. So in 80% of our footprint, we have 80-plus percent market share in these local DMAs. So while we are in places like New York and L.A. and Atlanta and Chicago, our bread and butter and what makes us unique is the absolute dominance we have in places like Little Rock and Baton Rouge and Tallahassee and Boise, Des Moine and places like that. That insulates us somewhat from stormy weather, if you will. And certainly, in the post-COVID world, our smaller- and medium-sized markets are returning to normal much faster than our markets that are in the sort of top 10, 15 DMAs in the country. So we'll start with -- we have a tremendous moat around our business. Highly regulated industry that protects those market shares that I described, regulated at the federal level, the state level and the local level. And by the time you layer all those over each other, it's -- you're playing 3 dimension chess to try to get a new goal, which is good for us as the incumbent, right?

Heavily local in our mix of business. 75% of our business comes from local customers, tens of thousands of them that are touched by almost 1,000 account executives at the local level. So 75% local, 25% national. The COVID experience has been such that national has fallen harder and has taken longer to come back. Our local customers are coming back faster. And as I like to say now there, most of our verticals are normalizing in our book just the way they traditionally have.

So it's a great business model. We gen a lot of free cash flow. We have the best balance sheet in the industry by a long shot. We were, thanks to Jay and his team, as positioned as well as we could be to go into this thing. As a matter of fact, we just called $535 million worth of our bonds. Because we feel that good about our prospects going forward, we didn't feel like we needed to hang on to that extra liquidity and used our cash and a little bit of our revolver and tapped the capital markets and took out those bonds just recently.

The balance sheet stuff we've done this year is going to dramatically reduce our interest expense next year. It's going to go from $135 million this year to about $115 million next year. Pretty dramatic improvement. We're a REIT. And while it was painful to have to announce that we were cutting our distribution, unlike a lot of REITs, we didn't eliminate it. We reduced it, and we fully anticipate as we recover increasing it off that $2.50 base. So for people that aren't all that familiar with REIT economics and REIT accounting, the key metric is AFFO per share, and from that is derived your distribution requirement.

And this year, if it plays out like we think it will, our payout ratio is actually going to be less than it has been historically. So that suggests we have headroom to raise it going into (inaudible). So that's my expectation on 2021. It's too early to start opining on 2021, but others have so I'll quote them. Most -- as you know, most of the pundits that try to predict what ad spend is going to be are seeing an up year next year. A number that seems to be bandied about most is about 7% 2021 ad spend over 2020. If that's our backdrop, then we're going to have a good year. So again, that's not guidance, and I'm quoting somebody else. But if that is our fate, then we're going to do just fine.

DANIEL B. POWELL: Understood. No, that's all really helpful. And definitely, a couple of things we want to sort of dig into there as the session goes on. Maybe over the next couple of months and quarters, I know there's a lot of macro uncertainty out there. But as you sort of alluded to in some of those industry forecasts, things look like they're getting better, things are starting to normalize. What are sort of the key priorities in place for Lamar? Recognizing with 80% market share in 80% of your market, some of that is just doing what you do well. But any key priorities you would call out as you sort of navigate some of the uncertainty in the market here over the next couple of months?

SEAN E. REILLY: Sure. So I think the first thing is beginning to play a little offense instead of playing defense. And in Q2, we did that with our balance sheet. And we are beginning to do that by freeing up some CapEx dollars and maybe some acquisition dollars and feeling confident enough in what we're seeing to, again, as I say, play a little offense instead of playing defense. So I would say that's the first thing we're doing.

The second thing we're doing is making sure we execute on a couple of fronts. We have seen a nice rebound in our programmatic book of business. It evaporated to nothing in April, May, June. And this month, we may well do as much business in September of '20 as we did in September of '19. So I'm feeling really good about the rebound in our programmatic business. And that should bode well for the fourth quarter, and we need to make sure we continue to execute on that.

Political is also a nice tailwind. Political book of business is pacing substantially ahead of the last cycle, and that's going to help us as we go down the stretch. I said on the call that I felt like we had a shot at the upper end of the guidance we gave for AFFO per share, and I'm feeling even better about that now. I feel like we have a good shot at the upper end.

So the tone of business feels good. Obviously, there's some weak geographies still out there, primarily in the West. Vegas is still struggling. Southern California is still struggling. Seattle is struggling. But much of Lamar land is normalizing and feeling really good going into 2021.

DANIEL B. POWELL: That's good to hear. So in early August, you laid out on the earnings call some of the sectors that were doing really well like health care, home improvement and mentioned some that are still challenged. Since then with some of the back-to-school dynamics and more normalization, have you seen any changes in those conversations with those client groups or any insights you're getting from those groups?

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. I would say, as I like to describe it, most of the verticals are normalizing. Things are actually better in that regard than actually when we were on that call. The one thing that hasn't changed is local is still substantially stronger than national. And so to truly rebound, we need a more robust national ad spend picture. And then we still have that vertical out there that's very important to us that is still struggling, which is amusements, entertainment and sports. That's for obvious reasons, we're not getting together in large gatherings. And for -- again, for us to really rebound and have a robust 2021, we need to have that rebound as well because it's not just event organizers or promoters or participants advertising with us, although they do. That's that 80%. It's also the ancillary economic activity that those things generate. Without the big trade shows, Vegas won't be Vegas, right? And again, it's not just the electronics show participants or promoters advertising with us, although they do, it's all the ancillary economic activity that happens in Vegas around it. It creates a backdrop for better, stronger customers coming our way. So that needs to rebound. Again, for Lamar, in general and out-of-home and -- or I should say, out-of-home in general and Lamar in particular to fully rebound, we need to have a rebound in amusements, entertainment and sports.

DANIEL B. POWELL: And it sounds like that falls a little bit on the lines of small versus larger markets. And I know there's been somewhat of a split there. The national decline was sort of nearly 2x what you're seeing at the more local level. Has that gap started to close, widen, stay the same?

SEAN E. REILLY: I think it's slowly closing, and I've got some hopes that Q4 national is going to come on a little stronger. We've had some real success stories on the national front. Insurance has come on real, real strong, GEICO, Allstate, State Farm. So they're -- they've been with us in numbers that are larger than last year. Beverages, same story, doing strong there. But there's a huge category that just hasn't come out of this thing yet, and that's entertainment. And now I'm not talking about events, I'm talking about movies, right, and streaming video. And they're big buyers, and we need them to get healthy. We need movie business to get healthy again. And then finally, one thing we are seeing and I think a little recovery in is big tech. This is anecdotal, but Lamar has the largest painted wall in the world in New York City, and it's that big wall right outside of Penn Station on 42nd Street. And Apple just bought it, and they're paying a great rate and they committed through the end of the year. That's anecdotal, but I mean that's a big commitment. You're talking north of $200,000 a month to rent that wall. So that's -- again, it's just a little data point, little anecdotal, but it's good to see.

DANIEL B. POWELL: Right, absolutely. Is there anything from those names that might be anecdotal? But are you getting a sense that there's more optimism heading into Q4, which just seasonally is a good period for advertising? Or are people still kind of in wait-and-see mode and not sort of ready to be more optimistic about a Q4 in 2020 yet?

SEAN E. REILLY: So here's what John Miller is telling me, he's our Head of National Sales. It's -- he says, activity, and that's just RFPs out there, proposals, inquiries, inbound, just activity, right, not necessarily contracts, is almost back to March levels in terms of just activity. So there is some buzz going on out there on the national side. However, because they're not -- Apple notwithstanding the big painted wall, because for the most part, they're not targeting the larger DMAs, the dollars aren't as much, if that makes sense to you. So the good news is activity, national ad spend, national agencies, national brands are beginning to find their voice and decide where they want to put their ad spend. That's the good news. On this sort of still challenging front, the dollars aren't pouring into -- as much into New York, Chicago, L.A., et cetera.

DANIEL B. POWELL: Understood. No, that makes a lot of sense, but good to hear on the activity levels that you're starting to get back to some of the pre-COVID levels.

A bit earlier in the year, you took some restructuring actions. I think about $60 million in cost savings was what you're sort of targeting. Could you sort of help us understand where those costs are coming from and sort of how that positions Lamar on the other side? Are there areas that you'll need to reinvest in as things recover? Or are those more permanent and that's where they're coming from?

SEAN E. REILLY: Great question. The news there is good. It's actually better than we expected. It looks like we're going to wring about $75 million out of our cost OpEx base, which is a little better than the $60 million we put out there. For next year, assuming next year is a pretty decent recovery year, let's use the 7% '21 over '20 that the pundits are throwing out there, if that happens on the top line, then about half of that $75 million comes back into our expense base, basically because it toggles around the top line, right? Sales commissions, revenue shares both in transit and some of our ground leases for our traditional billboards, cash bonuses for general managers, all that sort of stuff, that's going to come back. But about half of it won't, so we'll be coming off a substantially smaller expense base for '20. Again, about half of that $75 million comes back into the expense base. And then on top of that, you'll have 1% to 2% of our normal inflation in our expense base. So armed with all of that, you could pretty -- get pretty close to what our OpEx is going to look like in 2021. I just gave you a lot of information that you could probably get pretty close if you're modeling us. So that's good news, right? Because if we do grow the top in that 7% range, the bottom will grow double digits, if you do all that, right? So I think we're positioned well in terms of how we've positioned our OpEx.

On the CapEx side, we dramatically curtailed our CapEx, both growth and maintenance. I've got a working number that I'm kind of throwing out there for next year. This isn't guidance. It's just sort of how are we feeling now. I'll have a better number in November when we're on that call. But I'm thinking $100 million in total CapEx next year, $50 million of it growth and $50 million of it maintenance, and that should take care of us. My team may come up and they may say, "Sean, we cut it back to the bone this year, so you got a little catch up next year." So maybe it's a little bigger than that number, but that's my working number right now.

On the growth CapEx side, again, not guidance, just sort of thinking through if we've got a good macro, what should we expect to do in digital deployment? I'm thinking there's some pent-up demand from this year, the digitals we didn't do this year, plus our normal run rate of a little north of $200 million or so. So that number could be around $300 million. And that would sort of -- that sort of feels right, right now. It would require that we have a little macro tailwind next year, which it isn't a great leap of faith to think that we can't grow 7% over what happened in Q2 and Q3 and -- so anyway, that's -- it's way too early in the game for me to have gone through all that arithmetic with you, but I just think in a COVID world, I just owe you guys all the information I can give you on what we're seeing. And just keep in mind, that's subject to change.

DANIEL B. POWELL: No. That's all extremely helpful. Great. Stuff is changing every day, but always helpful to sort of hear the latest thoughts. Maybe coming back to something you mentioned earlier in your priorities about going on the offensive a little bit more. You're comfortably within your leverage covenants, the May deal priced well. If things begin to recover more meaningfully, could we see you getting more aggressive and leveraging up to go after opportunities? What might an opportunity look like in order for it to be worth you going down that road?

SEAN E. REILLY: So we still want to get back to where our leverage was, around 4x. So -- and by the time -- the best way to get there is to operate your way there, right, grow the EBITDA so that just sort of happens organically. There may, however, be a little bit of pressure to pay down a little debt. So I think if 2021 plays out the way we hope, I think it's a real good conversation for us to have with shareholders about what we ought to do with the excess cash. Because it could well be that shareholders say, "Look, I don't want you paying down debt that's costing you less than 2%. You can get a better return going and buying billboards." And so that may well be how that conversation goes.

I don't think our strategy, if you will, has changed because of COVID. I think you're going to see us play the acquisition playbook in a very familiar way. In other words, you've got this long tail of independents, small transactions. Very easy for us to accretively deploy $100 million, $120 million, $150 million doing those cookie-cutter tuck-in acquisitions, right? I think you're going to see that as we turn the corner into next year.

There may be some larger independents that kind of get in trouble through this whole experience that were maybe a little too levered going in. If you've got 7x leverage in March, by the time December rolls around, that could be 10x, right? And that's a troubled place to be, and I do know there's some independents of decent size that have found themselves there. So that might create an opportunity.

DANIEL B. POWELL: No, that makes a lot of sense. That makes a lot of sense. I guess as -- we talked a little bit about the tailwind from political. How should we think about the political calendar in this year, acknowledging it hasn't been like most other election years? But it sounded like from what you're seeing, it's tracking a little bit better than the last cycle. So just curious to hear what the implications would be for Lamar on a local versus national level.

SEAN E. REILLY: Sure. Most of our political is local, although we did get some interesting presidential buys this year just because it was such a -- was and continues to be a rather extraordinary year. So last presidential, we did $6 million or $7 million in total political. So that was 2016. 2018, we did $11 million, and it was not a presidential year. Had COVID not hit, I think we were destined to do $16 million, $17 million, $18 million this year. Obviously, the second quarter just totally blew all that up. But in spite of all that, I think we'll end up the year doing about $13 million or a little north of $13 million in political. So even in spite of COVID, we're sequentially better than the last cycle. And the bulk of that is hitting in -- obviously, in the back half of the year, which has provided a nice little tailwind.

For years and years and years, I didn't even talk about political because it just wasn't, number one, that important in our book. And number two, it wasn't odd year, even year, odd year, even year phenomenon. Literally, we would get a few million bucks every year because some of the local elections are off cycle. It's become increasingly important, and I think it's because our digital platform is responsive in a way that political campaigns need. They got to change their message overnight, right, and we can do that for them. So I think that's one reason why it's becoming more important in our book. And of course, the other reason is, as a society, we're spending incredible amounts of money on politics these days.

DANIEL B. POWELL: Sure. No, yes, definitely been very visible and top of mind for a lot of people the last couple of years and this one in particular.

So you mentioned digital there a little bit. Is there -- maybe spend a couple of minutes if we could talk about just sort of the digital presence at Lamar. Maybe from a tools and technology, infrastructure perspective, how is the company positioned in a world and almost any slice in the market you look at that is moving more digital?

SEAN E. REILLY: We are in great shape. We've got an incredible team that does this for us. In particular, Ian Dallimore gets lots of accolades in the industry, talks at all the industry gatherings about the promise of programmatic and how we're going about it. So I feel really good about where we are.

Now of the big 3 companies, we all have little nuances on how we approach technology that are a little bit different. I'm not going to say one is better than the other, they're just different. And so to kind of sort of help understand our approach, our approach is totally open architecture, totally driven by third-party data sources that are off the shelf, not proprietary. And we take that approach for a couple of reasons. Internally, I've always believed in open architecture. I just think that's the best way to stay state-of-the-art, if you will. But also what we're discovering from our customers is that they have their own views about which data sets prove out that we've delivered the impressions and that those impressions meet their goals, right? And if we're wedded to one data set, and let's call the customer Target, and Target wants to use a different one, then that complicates their ability to transact with us. There's lots and lots of data sets that come off of this thing, right? And every customer sort of has their little take on proving out that they've met their goals with their campaign. So we're open architecture, third-party data sets. Oftentimes, our customers pay for the data sets. So that's not even an expense we bear, which is another reason to do it on a campaign-by-campaign basis because you can lay it off if you handle it correctly.

So anyway, that's our approach to it. And if you have that open philosophy to your architecture, then you're pretty much always going to be state-of-the-art because there's lots of off-the-shelf stuff you can turn to stay state-of-the-art. So anyway, I hope I answered your question, but that's sort of our philosophy and where we are.

DANIEL B. POWELL: No, that's extremely helpful and definitely I want to follow-up on it. But I also want to remind anyone participating that if you've got questions, please submit them through the chat, and we're happy to pick the most challenging ones to send over to Sean. I'm just kidding. So if you'd like to post anything in the chat, please pass those through.

But I wanted to come back to the comment that you made on programmatic. You'd said September '20 was looking like it was going to be up over September '19. Was that the...

SEAN E. REILLY: I got a shot at it. Keep in mind that we -- programmatic is -- there's no contracts, and we bill in arrears, right? So I'm not going to be able to know exactly where September falls out until I get to the end of the month. But the chatter is really good. We're getting really good guidance from our partners. In particular, Vistar and Place Exchange are saying that their pipeline feels good. And that's where it starts, right? It starts with them. And so no, I feel good. It feels -- for that product category, it feels like very much a V recovery.

DANIEL B. POWELL: And is that -- in your mind, is that being driven by because people can get really deep into the data, it's more measurable? What have sort of been the factors that made that look more like a V shape for you all?

SEAN E. REILLY: I think that's it. We're much, much, much more rigorous about proving out impressions in our programmatic platform because we have to, right? We don't do that with our other products. We give them audience estimates. We can tell them demographic information. We can tell them how many eyeballs and where those eyeballs have been and where they're going, but we don't have to guarantee impressions. In programmatic, we do, right? We only collect on impressions delivered. So I think that's one point.

But it's also a truism in our industry that the shorter the cycle to sale, the quicker it falls off when times get really, really tough, but also the quicker it recovers when the economy recovers. And that's proven itself out this time around. Programmatic is the absolute shortest cycle sale we have. It's a nanosecond, right? And it (inaudible). Digital is the next shorter cycle sale, and it fell harder and is recovering at a faster rate. Our next shortest cycle sale is posters, right? They're sold in 1-month to 3-month increments. Fell a little harder than bulletins, recovering a little faster. And then, of course, bulletins are sold in 6-month increments, 9-month increments, annual increments, and that's just a little steadier, right?

So it's interesting to see how it plays out differently across different products. But it's usually, as I said, shorter cycle, fall a little harder, come back a little quicker.

DANIEL B. POWELL: That makes sense. We got a question coming through chat, talking a little bit more about some of the near-term trends. I'll try to kind of paraphrase. But you talked about some of those national advertisers who are starting to come back, but it's sort of mixing to smaller markets and so the dollar amount is a little bit smaller. In some of these areas where you're seeing these recoveries, is it fair to assume that, that means you're seeing a little bit more of a recovery around occupancy than you are on pricing? Or sort of how can you help us understand how those 2 pieces are working?

SEAN E. REILLY: Great question. In general, I'm happy with how we're hanging in there on rate in most of our markets. So the recovery is in occupancy, I would say, as it's sort of general proposition. There's lots of exceptions when you really dig into it, but as a general statement, I think that's accurate.

And again, reflective of Lamar's focus in primarily middle and small markets. The larger markets, it's a different story. And then within that story, it depends on where you are and what our product mix is in a large market. So for example, Los Angeles is really struggling for us. Our product there is primarily small format posters, and we compete against the slightly larger but still small format posters that Clear Channel and Outfront have in that market, and that's creating some competitive friction and some cross fire that is causing it to be a little more difficult for us to maintain rate on that product, right? That makes sense. But then you go to a Dallas, we're a #3 bulletin player there. Our distribution is good. We don't have quite as much inventory to move, so the inventory we have is moving, and it feels better in Dallas than it does in Los Angeles. And then I guess the -- between those 2 extremes of big market pressure is Atlanta. In Atlanta, we're, gosh, strong, strong 3, if not #2 in the market. A lot of inventory to move. It's all bulletins. And it can get a little Darwinian as the 3 big companies compete for business on the national front. So that kind of gives you a feel for big market, small market. And even within big markets, it matters what inventory you have.

DANIEL B. POWELL: Sure. No, that makes a lot of sense. I know we're coming up on time, have a couple of minutes left here. So I wanted to make sure -- and we touched on it a little bit earlier in the call, but just the capital allocation strategy. I know that you said those cost cuts are performing a little bit ahead of your expectations. Payout ratio is a little bit lower this year than in the past, but also discussed going on the offensive a little bit. So just curious to your sort of the capital allocation strategy plans from here.

SEAN E. REILLY: Yes. I think it's going to sound really familiar with one exception, and that being do we take advantage of the opportunity to pay down a little debt next year. But other than that, I think it's going to sound really familiar. Start with what you think our EBITDA is going to be, subtract our interest obligations, subtract a little bit of tax leakage, subtract, as I mentioned, give or take, $100 million in total CapEx, and then what you have left is your distribution. And I tell people to back into that. Leave me at the end of the day with a little over $100 million to do long tail acquisitions, and you can sort of back into what the distribution is probably going to look like. And I think if you just kind of think of it that way, it's going to sound really, really familiar to people that have followed Lamar for a long time. Again, with the exception of do we pay down $150 million to $200 million in debt next year. Because I can see my way to leverage that's below 4x by the end of next year, if we, number one, execute on the EBITDA number; and number two, pay down a little debt.

DANIEL B. POWELL: Right. No, that makes sense. Maybe come back to revisit some of the programmatic stuff a little bit. Have you been seeing -- even if you're able to think sort of outside the impact of COVID, what does sort of adoption looks like within programmatic sort of across the industries that you're exposed to? Is there the potential that some are sort of behind in terms of their adoption that could create a tailwind? Or is there too much concentration in the programmatic book that something could throw it off the trend?

SEAN E. REILLY: So first of all, it's all national. And in terms of verticals, it's pretty widely spread out, so it's not really concentrated. You could look at an individual month and say, okay, well, there's concentration there. So for example, if you look just at September, you're going to see a whole lot of FanDuel and DraftKings, right, because they're coming in, and they use programmatic. So I don't think it's vertical or customer concentrated in a broad definition of the sense.

There are early adopters and there are late adopters. One thing we're focused laser-like on is making sure that we have walled it off that platform off from our traditional national buyer because we want to make sure it's net new dollars to us. And so that, by definition, means you're going to early adopters because you're only going to digital shops, period. And what's interesting is some of those digital shops are buried within the brands themselves because they're actually buying direct from us with -- the digital shop within General Motors is making the buy, not the agency, right, which is another indication that it's net new dollars because otherwise, those shops wouldn't have had the ability to even transact with us. If you don't go through the black box algorithm, we're not picking up the phone, sorry, right? So I feel good about the prospects for that going forward. I feel like I can look our investors in the eyes and say, "Look, this is net new dollars right now." As that platform grows, it's going to be harder and harder for me to prove that out. And invariably, there's going to be some crossover and some cannibalization, but I do think it's incremental demand for our digital platform that causes the whole platform to lift.

DANIEL B. POWELL: No, that makes a lot of sense, and I think that's probably a good place to wrap things up. Sean, thanks so much for joining us today. And I know I'm hoping as well as you're hoping as someone in Baton Rouge that local economic activity comes back with the fall football season this year.

SEAN E. REILLY: Oh, yes. Baton Rouge is always a better place when Tiger stadium is rocking.

DANIEL B. POWELL: Absolutely, absolutely. Well, we look forward to catching as many night games possible. But thanks so much for joining us, Sean. Really appreciate the time today.

SEAN E. REILLY: All right. I appreciate it, Daniel, and thanks, everybody, for listening.

DANIEL B. POWELL: Thanks, everyone.
